ailab.utils package¶

Submodules¶

ailab.utils.config module¶

class ailab.utils.config.Config(cfginput)[source]¶

Bases: dict

Configuration file read from yaml, inherit from python dictionary

Input:
  • cfginput: yaml filepath, python dictionary, argparse.namespace
Usage:
  • cfg.a.b
  • cfg[‘a’][‘b’]
update(cfginput)[source]¶

update configurations from other configurations

input:
  • cfginput: Config object for python dictionary

ailab.utils.graph module¶

class ailab.utils.graph.Graph(connections=None, directed=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Create a graph structure with node and edge. Support directed graph and undirected graph

Input:
  • connections: one can input existed connections, default is [], format is [[node1, node2], …]
  • directed: True or False, directed or undirected, default is False
add(node1, node2)[source]¶

add a connection for two nodes

Input:
  • node1: string
  • node2: string
add_connections(connections)[source]¶

add connections

Input:
  • connections: [[node1, node2], …]

ailab.utils.logger module¶

ailab.utils.logger.setLogger(cfg_input)[source]¶

return a logging object

input:
  • cfg_input: a python dictionary or a ailab.utils.config object
    • config keys:
      • APPNAME: string, default is ‘NLPLAB’
      • LogLevel_Console: console loglevel, default is 10
      • LogLevel_File: file loglevel, default is 0
      • LogFile: log file path, default is empty
      • LogFormat: log format, default is ‘%(asctime)s | %(levelname)s: %(message)s’
output:
  • logging object

class ailab.utils.odsread.odsread(filename)[source]¶

Bases: object

read ods file

Input:
  • filename: ods filepath
getvalbycol(col)[source]¶

get value for special col

input:
  • row: col number
output:
  • value list
getvalbyrow(row)[source]¶

get value for special row

input:
  • row: row number
output:
  • value list
getvalue(row, col)[source]¶

get value with row and col number

input:
  • row: row number
  • col: col number
output:
  • value
parse(tablename)[source]¶

parse the ods table

input:
  • tablename: string

ailab.utils.qnaread module¶

class ailab.utils.qnaread.QnARead(cfg)[source]¶

Bases: object

readQnA(subset=None)[source]¶

Auto read QnA from different sources

Config keys needed:
  • question_db_type: mysql or xls or csv
  • question_header: needed table header, list of string
  • other keys needed for different sources
Input:
  • subset: array-like, Labels along other axis to consider, e.g. if you are dropping rows these would be a list of columns to include. More details please check pandas.dropna
readQnA_csv(subset=None)[source]¶

Read QnA from csv

Config keys needed:
  • question_file: csv filename
  • question_sep: csv separate symbol
Input:
  • subset: array-like, Labels along other axis to consider, e.g. if you are dropping rows these would be a list of columns to include. More details please check pandas.dropna
readQnA_mysql(subset=None, limit=0, offset=0)[source]¶

Read QnA from MySQL

Config keys needed:
  • question_host: MySQL host
  • question_database: MySQL database
  • question_tbname: MySQL table name
  • question_port: MySQL port
  • question_user: MySQL username
  • question_password: MySQL password
Input:
  • subset: array-like, Labels along other axis to consider, e.g. if you are dropping rows these would be a list of columns to include. More details please check pandas.dropna
readQnA_xls(subset=None)[source]¶

Read QnA from excel

Config keys needed:
  • question_file: xls filename
  • question_sheetname: xls tablename
Input:
  • subset: array-like, Labels along other axis to consider, e.g. if you are dropping rows these would be a list of columns to include. More details please check pandas.dropna

ailab.utils.utils module¶

ailab.utils.utils.envread(keys)[source]¶

use environment variables to cover original environment

input:
  • keys: a key list need to read from environment
output:
  • python dictionary {key:value, …}
ailab.utils.utils.flat_list(l)[source]¶

flatten a 2-d list to 1-d list

input:
  • l: 2-d list
output:
  • 1-d list
ailab.utils.utils.hashword(word, hashsize=16777216)[source]¶

hash the word using murmurhash3_32 to a positive int value

input:
  • word: string format word
  • hashsize: maximum number, default is 16777216
output:
  • int
ailab.utils.utils.lang_detect(string)[source]¶

language detection using langdetect

input:
  • string
output:
  • most possible language
ailab.utils.utils.ldumps(value)[source]¶

serialize and compress variable to string using lzo and pickle

input:
  • value: python variable
output:
  • serialized string
ailab.utils.utils.lloads(value)[source]¶

load serialized string from ldumps

input:
  • value: serialized string
output:
  • python variable
ailab.utils.utils.normalize(text)[source]¶

resolve different type of unicode encodings using unicodedata.normalize

input:
  • text: string
output:
  • string
ailab.utils.utils.restpost(url, data)[source]¶

rest client post using requests

input:
  • url: restapi’s url
  • data: python dictionary
output:
  • json format post return, if failed will return None
ailab.utils.utils.status_check(filename)[source]¶

load a status string from file

input:
  • filename: file path
output:
  • status string
  • if filename not existed, return 0
ailab.utils.utils.status_save(filename, status)[source]¶

save a status string to file

input:
  • filename: file path
  • status: status string
ailab.utils.utils.zdump(value, filename)[source]¶

serialize compress variable to file using zlib and pickle

input:
  • value: python variable
  • filename: saved file path
ailab.utils.utils.zdumps(value)[source]¶

serialize and compress variable to string using zlib and pickle

input:
  • value: python variable
output:
  • serialized string
ailab.utils.utils.zload(filename)[source]¶

load compressed pkl file from zdump

input:
  • filename: saved file path
output:
  • python variable
ailab.utils.utils.zloads(value)[source]¶

load serialized string from zdumps

input:
  • value: serialized string
output:
  • python variable
